ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to write concisely and persuasively as well as to analyze non-fiction texts.
I learned how to write the personal essay and closely evaluate creative non-fiction readings. I also developed a writing voice and learned how use satire in writing.
I learned various writing techniques and styles, as well as honed my own writing style throughout multiple essays covering different topics.
I learned how to write creatively with more attention to detail in each sentence instead of the overall picture of the essay.
I improved my writing through learning and trying various techniques, and had the chance to read some really well-crafted essays from a wide range of writers!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was an amazing course. No particular things to improve on.

Because of the small class size, going to class felt much more personal. Feedback on drafts and essays is very clear, and the setup of one week for a draft, one week to edit was helpful. The readings are diverse and very interesting.

Strengths: The readings were superb, and the workshops for essays helped my revision process. In addition, the small seminar-style was very beneficial for discussion.

Weaknesses: I think we could have more time to work on each draft; sometimes, we only had a week or a little more to submit a first draft.

I like how the course was structured, but I think that sometimes the amount of reading that we had was a bit excessive. We didn't always get to everything that we read and it was generally overwhelming to try to use a lot of techniques that we discussed in class in our writing. I like the discussion aspect of it though because the readings that were confusing became understood by the end of class and you were able to get live feedback on your writing during workshops. 
Another critique that I have is that it seemed like we had all the time in the world to write the first two essays then all of the sudden the deadlines for first and final drafts of the last two essays seemed back to back. That doesn't even take into account the usual 5th essay that was made optional due to Covid. I think that the essays should be spaced out better to avoid this claustrophobic feeling that encourages rushed essays.

The course was well-organized, and the readings were generally really interesting! The only weakness I can think of is that the amount of time we had for essays varied  particularly toward the end, some of the essays felt rushed.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The breakout rooms and interview assignment helped the class become engaged as we got to know each other more.
The virtual discussion/lectures were very engaging, and the workshops for essays was also helpful in improving my writing.

I think that the live workshops where students got both peer and professor feedback on their essay was extremely helpful. I also like how participation was both encouraged and required in the course because it made discussion flow much easier.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. This is a great class that makes you a better writer in one semester. It does take up more time than the average course but it is very worth it.

Yes! Ms. Jones is so passionate about readings and her students' writing. You'll learn how to develop your voice as a writer and analyze pieces of writing (and sentences!) more closely. Workshops are helpful in getting ideas from other students on what to add or change in a paper. You'll also learn more about yourself as a person.

Yes, definitely. You not only improve your own writing, but learn about different techniques and styles from many notable authors. It also gives you lots of freedom in choosing what topic to write about, even though there are around 4 or 5 "units"

The course itself was fine. It wasn't necessarily my favorite topic, but as far as writing goes, it allowed for a lot of creativity. It also allowed for a lot of individual attention to your writing which was helpful. I would say take the course if you like narrative writing, but try to find another writing credit if you don't.
Yes! This is a great writing course to take, regardless of your major.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
1 on 1 zoom meetings with the professor as well.
